title: Kumis
summary: Kumis (also spelled kumiss or koumiss or kumys, see other transliterations and cognate words below under terminology and etymology –  Kazakh: қымыз, qymyz) Mongolian: айраг, ääryg) is a fermented dairy product traditionally made from mare's milk or donkey milk. The drink remains important to the peoples of the Central Asian steppes, of Turkic and Mongol origin: Kazakhs, Bashkirs, Kalmyks, Kyrgyz, Mongols, and Sakha.[1] Kumis was historically consumed by the Khitan, Jurchen, Hungarians and Han Chinese of North China as well.[2]
